questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain, distension, bloody or mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs, the possible causative agent is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura(Whipworm).

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

In heavy infections of 200 adults worms or more (Trichuris dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain and tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, rectal prolapse, moderate eosinophilia, and the clubbing of fingers.

Chronic infection leads to impaired childhood growth, poor physical fitness, and nutritional status. 

Treatment: Mebendazole or albendazole.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in a patient who has undergone organ transplantation?
questions.solution:
Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug of choice for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients like patients who have undergone organ transplantation and HIV-positive patients.

Other drugs that can be used for prophylaxis are:

  • Aerosolized pentamidine
  • Dapsone
  • Dapsone plus pyrimethamine
  • Atovoquone

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the vagina is ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the vagina is non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

The stratified squamous epithelia are subdivided into two types: keratinized and non-keratinized.

Keratinized epithelium: It is present over the surface that is subjected to high levels of abrasion and drying.

It is seen in

  • Entire epidermis
  • Mucocutaneous junction of the lips, nostrils, distal anal canal, the outer surface of the tympanic membrane
  • Parts of the oral cavity: gingivae, hard palate and filiform papillae on the anterior part of the dorsal surface of the tongue

Non-keratinized epithelium: It is present over the surface that is subjected to abrasion but not drying.

It is seen in

  • The lining of the oral cavity except the parts mentioned above
  • Oropharynx and laryngopharynx
  • Esophagus
  • Part of the anal canal
  • Vagina
  • Distal uterine cervix
  • Distal urethra
  • Cornea
  • Inner surfaces of the eyelids
  • Vestibule of the nasal cavities

questions.text: The following picture shows the composition of solute in the urine and plasma sample of 3 patients. Identify the true statement.

choices.text: A shows negative free water clearance, B is isotonic, C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance
A shows negative free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance

questions.solution:
Patient A shows positive free water clearance, B isotonic and C shows negative free water clearance.

Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, when dilute or concentrated urine is being formed.

Patient A has positive free-water clearance since excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Patient B has a similar concentration of plasma and urine, making them isotonic fluids in this patient.

Patient C has negative free-water clearance since excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.text: A medical student was doing research in a laboratory that studies the neuromuscular junction. Which of the following events at the junction are listed in correct sequential order?

choices.text: Motor neuron action potential, acetylcholine release, Ca2+ entry at the endplate
Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, acetylcholine release, Na+ entry at the endplate
Ca2+ entry into the motor nerve terminal, Na+ entry at the endplate, motor neuron action potential
Na+ entry at the endplate, acetylcholine release, muscle fiber action potential

questions.solution:
Events Occurring at the Chemical Synapse:

The action potential arriving at the end of the motor neuron increases the permeability of its endings to Ca2+

                                                                        ↓

Ca2+ enters the endings and triggers a marked increase in exocytosis of the acetylcholine-containing synaptic vesicles

                                                                        ↓

Binding of acetylcholine to nicotinic receptors increases the Na+ and K+ conductance

                                                                        ↓

Resultant influx of Na+ produces a local depolarizing potential, the endplate potential

                                                                        ↓

The current created by this local potential depolarizes the adjacent muscle membrane to its firing level

                                                                        ↓

Action potentials are generated on either side of the endplate and are conducted away from the endplate in both directions along the muscle fiber. This muscle action potential, in turn, initiates muscle contraction.

Acetylcholine is then removed from the synaptic cleft by acetylcholinesterase, which is present in high concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be seen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

questions.text: Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against ________.
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against Hepatitis B and Tetanus

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste.

Yearly health check-ups should be done, and booster dose should be given if needed.

Reference: Biomedical Waste Management Rules, 2016 (http://envfor.nic.in/sites/default/files/BMW%20Rules,%202016_1.pdf)

questions.text: Which of the following is a large vessel vasculitis?
questions.solution: Takayasu arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Other options-

Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

questions.text: Which of the following is used for sterilisation of the following machine?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a heart-lung machine. It is sterilised by ethylene oxide gas.

Ethylene oxide gas diffuses through many types of porous materials and readily penetrates some plastics and is used for sterilising heart–lung machines, respirators, sutures, dental equipment, books and clothing.

questions.text: The best approach to the control of arthropods is ______
questions.solution:
• Principles of arthropod control include
    • Environmental control: This is the best approach to the control of arthropods
    • Chemical control: Use of insecticides, pesticides, etc.
    • Biological control: Larvivorous fish like Gambusia
    • Genetic control
    • Newer methods like chemosterilants, insect growth regulators, and sex attractants
    • Integrated approach involves usage of more than one modalities of arthropod control

questions.text: The embryonic development of the lens occurs from the _______.
questions.solution:
Surface ectoderm gives rise to the following structures:

  • Lens
  • Epithelial lining of conjunctiva and cornea
  • Epithelial lining of lacrimal glands and tarsal glands

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On further examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

Image: Horner Trantas spots

questions.text: A 56 yr old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face. 

Condition Site of lesion Description 
Chorea Striatum

Flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body
Athetosis Globus pallidus

Spontaneous, continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face
Hemiballusmus Subthalamic nucleus

Sudden flailing movements of an entire limb
Parkinsonism Substantia nigra

Severe rigidity, akinesia, and tremors

questions.text: Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis does not get a contribution from the middle cerebral artery.

The circle of Willis is located in the interpeduncular fossa at the base of the brain. It is an anastomosis between the internal carotid arteries and vertebral arteries. It allows the blood entering from either artery to be distributed to both the cerebral hemispheres.

The arteries forming the circle of Willis are:

  • Anterior communicating artery
  • Anterior cerebral arteries
  • Internal carotid arteries
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: Which of the following disability indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY is the best measure of overall burden of a disease in a defined population and effectiveness of interventions.

Disability Adjusted Life Years: Years of lost life prematurely (YLL) + Years lost of disability (YLD)

  • It can measure both mortality and disability together. 
  • Alzheimer's Disease has a lower DALY as it is a disease that mostly develops during old age due to which the YLL will be lower than other diseases that develop in a younger age group.
  • Generally, Road Traffic Accidents would be considered to have a high DALY as it is more prevalent in the younger age group and thus the YLL will be higher.

questions.text:
Which of the following are constituents of smokeless gunpowder?
  1. Nitrocellulose
  2. Potassium nitrate
  3. Nitroglycerine
  4. Nitroguanidine
  5. Sulphur
questions.solution:
Smokeless gunpowder contains nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose and nitroguanidine.

Related Pearl: Various types of gunpowder

  • Smokeless powder:
    • Nitrocellulose (single base)
    • Nitrocellulose & Nitroglycerine (double base)
    • Nitrocellulose, Nitroglycerine, and Nitroguanidine (triple base)
  • Smoke producing powders contain Black Powder:
    • Potassium nitrate
    • Charcoal
    • Sulphur
  • Semi-smokeless powder:
    • Mixture of 80% black and 20% of the smokeless powder

questions.text: Which of the following compounds in a patient's urine will not give a positive reaction to​ Benedict's test?
questions.solution:
Benedict’s test is a test for reducing sugars. Sucrose does not give a positive reaction to Benedict's test as it is a non-reducing sugar.

Principle: All monosaccharides and reducing disaccharides contain a free functional aldehyde or ketone group. When heated in the presence of an alkali, they are converted to enediols, which reduce the cupric compounds (Cu2+) present in Benedict's reagent to an insoluble precipitate of red cuprous oxide (Cu2O).

Composition of Benedict’s reagent:

  • Copper sulfate: Provides the source of cupric (Cu2+) ions
  • Sodium citrate: Complexes with cupric (Cu2+) ions to prevent its deterioration to cuprous ions spontaneously
  • Sodium carbonate: Provides an alkaline pH

Substances giving a positive reaction on Benedict’s test:

  • All monosaccharides such as glucose, galactose, fructose, pentoses
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose and maltose
  • Glucuronic acid, homogentisic acid, and ascorbic acid

Clinical correlate: Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of glucose in urine.

The color of the precipitate gives a rough idea of the amount of sugar present in urine. Hence, it is a semi-quantitative test.

Colour of the precipitate Amount of reducing sugar
Green 0.5%
Yellow 1%
Orange 1.5%
Red 2%

questions.text: Most common route of spread of infection in ASOM is:
questions.solution:
Eustachian tube:

  • It is the most common route.
  • Infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics.
  • The infection can spread from the external ear through a traumatic perforation or via the blood but it is rare.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for congenital cataract is _______.

choices.text: Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant
Pars plana lensectomy with no IOL implant

questions.solution:
Cataract surgery with intraocular lens (IOL) implant is the treatment of choice in congenital cataract.

Cataract surgery for congenital cataract includes Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with primary posterior capsulorhexis and anterior vitrectomy.

Intracapsular cataract extraction [ICCE] is contraindicated in children.

After removal of the cataractous lens, posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) is implanted.

Timing of surgery

The critical period for the development of the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is 2–4 months of age.

Any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age, and the earliest possible time is preferred.

  • Bilateral dense cataract: early surgery by 4-6 weeks of age
  • Unilateral dense cataract or involving visual axis: urgent surgery within days

questions.text: A patient developed the following deformity, after overhead (weight-lifting) exercises. Which of the following muscle is involved?
questions.solution:
The image shows winging of the scapula which is pulled upwards and towards the spine. This is due to paralysis of the serratus anterior which is supplied by the long thoracic nerve.

When the patient is asked to push against a wall with both hands, the medial border of the scapula on the affected side becomes prominent and this is known as ‘winging of the scapula.’

Scapular winging is almost always caused by damage to one of three nerves that control muscles in your arms, back, and neck:

  • The long thoracic nerve, which controls the serratus anterior muscle
  • The dorsal scapular nerve, which controls the rhomboid muscles
  • The spinal accessory nerve, which controls the trapezius muscle

 The muscles of the back and their innervation are:

questions.text: An ICU patient dies due to cardiac failure. After some time, you notice that the deceased body has become cold. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of cooling of the body following a death is called algor mortis/ postmortem cooling.

After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. It is one of the early changes occurring after death. Temperature is usually measured in the rectum or abdominal cavity (subhepatic region).

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in a case of otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The definitive treatment for otosclerosis is surgery.

Stapedotomy is excision of superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice.

Stapedectomy is excision of the entire stapes (superstructutre + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated.

 

Note: Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome

Riboflavin (B2)

Cheilosis, Magenta-coloured tongue, 

Glossitis, Seborrheic dermatitis

Niacin (B3)

Pellagra

Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia

Pantothenic acid (B5)

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Pyridoxine (B6)

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, alopecia, paraesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, hallucinations

Folic acid (B9)

Megaloblastic anemia, neuropathy, neural tube defects, atrophic glossitis

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent URTI, impaired hearing, mouth breathing, failure to thrive, and high arched palate. Management is:
questions.solution: The patient is suffering from serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy causing eustachian tube obstruction. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

Other histologic features in the given image favouring the diagnosis of juvenile polyp:

  • Edematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells
  • Dilated glands filled with mucus

Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.

  • Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
  • Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below.
questions.solution: The test shown is Cover uncover test.

questions.text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors. 

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the mandibular left posterior region since 2 months. The swelling was initially small and quickly increased in size. Incisional biopsy was done, and histopathological analysis of the hematoxylin/eosin-stained material showed sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stain positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The tumour is most likely an embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

  • Rhabdomyosarcoma: Malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation
  • Three subtypes: alveolar (20%), embryonal (60%), and pleomorphic (20%).
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma (alveolar and embryonal): Most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood and adolescence.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.
  • The pediatric forms often arise in the sinuses, head and neck, and genitourinary tract.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma frequently contains fusions of the FOXO1 gene to either the PAX3 or the PAX7 gene, rearrangements marked by the presence of (2;13) or(1;13) translocations, respectively.
  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Rhabdomyoblasts with visible cross-striations may be present.
  • Sarcoma botryoids: variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina with cambium layer.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - Large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells
  • Immunohistochemistry: Positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin
  • The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
The most common end product of fatty acid synthesis is the saturated fatty acid, palmitic acid.

Acetyl CoA is the substrate of fatty acid synthesis and is the end product of fatty acid beta-oxidation.

questions.text: The optimum floor area  recommended per adult person in a living room is ________
questions.solution:
The optimum floor area recommended per adult person in a living room is 50 – 100 sq. ft.

Non-Rural Housing Standards in India:

Housing parameters

Description
Site

Elevated to protect from rains and floods.

Independent access to street.

Away from vector breeding sites and other pollutants like smoke, noise, dust.

Soil on which it is founded must be dry and safe.
Floor A pucca floor that is impermeable, easy to clean, free from cracks, damp-proof. Height of plinth must be 2 – 3 feet.
Walls 9 inch thick, strong, low heat capacity, weather resistant, unsuitable for harbourage of rats/vermin.
Roof Height not less than 10 feet (3m).
Rooms Number of rooms must be according to size of family but basic number is two.
Floor area A living room should have at least 120 sq. ft. of area for occupancy of more than 1 person and 100 sq. ft. for occupancy of only one person. 50 -100 sq. ft. floor area per person is optimum in a living room.
Cubic space 500 – 1000 cubic feet of air space per capita.
Windows At least 2 windows per room with one opening into an open space. Windows must be at a height of not more than 3 feet above ground. Window area must be 1/5th of floor area.
Lighting Daylight factor should be >1% over half the floor area.
Sanitary privy It is a must in every house.
Others Proper facilities for garbage disposal, bathing and washing and a good water supply.

questions.text: Which of the following structures cannot be accessed by performing an endoscopic nasal surgery?
questions.solution:
Cerebellum cannot be accessed by performing endoscopic nasal surgery.

Apart from the nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access the orbit, optic nerve, lacrimal sac, and pituitary gland.

Indications of advanced nasal endoscopic techniques:

  • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia

questions.text: What is the programme evaluation and review technique used for?
questions.solution:
The programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) is used for network analysis.

It is a type of quantitative management technique which helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle fibers consists of spindle-shaped myocytes?
questions.solution:
Smooth muscles consist of spindle-shaped myocytes.

Smooth muscles are specialised for slow steady contraction under the influence of autonomic nerves and various hormones. They are also called as visceral muscles.

They are the major component of blood vessels, digestive, respiratory, urinary and reproductive tracts.

In microscopy, smooth muscles can be identified by:

  • In longitudinal section, the spindle-shaped muscle cells are seen. They are elongated, tapering and unstriated cells with a centrally placed elongated nucleus.
  • In transverse section, the spindle-shaped cells are cut at different places along its length and hence are seen as a group of cells with different shapes and sizes. The nucleus is seen only in those cells, which are cut through the centre.

questions.text: Digestion of disaccharides occurs at_____
questions.solution:
Digestion of disaccharides occurs at the small intestine.

The enzymes maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase are located in the enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. The disaccharides are digested into their constituent monosaccharides as they come in contact with these enterocytes.

questions.text: A Chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion. It may or may not be related to pseudo membranes. On the tongue, there is a loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area. It can occur after long-term corticosteroids or antibiotics usage or those with HIV. Other names of this condition include Acute atrophic oral candidiasis and Antibiotic sore tongue.

Other options:

Burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is a burning sensation in the mouth with no underlying dental or medical cause where no related signs of disease are found in the mouth.

Geographic tongue, though consistent with the clinical image is not the best fit considering the clinical history. It is usually asymptomatic but can be occasionally associated with a sore tongue. It usually is associated with a history of being not constant in size, shape, or location.

Oral lichen planus is associated with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady has been on anti-epileptic therapy since childhood and now comes to the OPD seeking advice on a suitable method of contraception. Which contraceptive method should be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptives must be avoided or used cautiously in epilepsy.

The most important aspect to consider is the drug interactions between anti-epileptic drugs and contraceptives. There is no conclusive evidence on whether estrogen is beneficial or harmful for seizure control. 

Note: Convulsive disorder is not an absolute contraindication; it is safe to avoid but can be used with caution.

questions.text: Which is the best metabolic function of the lung?

choices.text: Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II

questions.solution:
Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II is the most significant metabolic function of the lungs.

This is mediated by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), located on the surface of endothelial cells in the pulmonary capillaries.

  • Synthesized and used in the lungs
    • Surfactant
  • Synthesized or stored and released into the blood
    • Prostaglandins
    • Histamine
    • Kallikrein
  • Partially removed from the blood
    • Prostaglandins
    • Bradykinin
    • Adenine nucleotides
    • Serotonin
    • Norepinephrine
    • Acetylcholine
  • Activated in the lungs
    • Angiotensin I → Angiotensin II

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
The given diagram depicts the change in volume with a change in intrapleural pressure, which is nothing but compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 

The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.

  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient is given a drug which is a non-competitive inhibitor of the carbonic anhydrase enzyme. Which of the following would be the effect of this drug?

choices.text: Decrease in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Non-competitive inhibitors cause a decrease in Vmax.

In non-competitive inhibition:

  • The inhibitor binds to the adjacent site and not the catalytic site of the enzyme
  • The catalytic property of the enzyme is reduced and hence Vmax is decreased
  • The affinity of the enzyme is not altered and hence Km is unaltered

questions.text: Fo-F1 complex, the ATP synthase inhibitor is ______.
questions.solution:
Oligomycin is a competitive inhibitor of the Fo complex.

                  Binds to the Fo domain of ATP synthase

                                          ↓

                        Closes the proton channel

                                          ↓

              Prevents the reentry of protons into the matrix

                                          ↓

             Stops the phosphorylation of ADP to ATP

questions.text: A dentist comes to the OPD with pain, redness, swelling of the finger. He also complains of fever. On examination, there are small, grouped vesicles with clear fluid in them. Tzanck smear is done which shows tzanck cells. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes herpetic whitlow. It is caused by HSV 1. It is often contracted by health care workers that come in contact with the virus; it is most commonly contracted by dental workers and medical workers exposed to oral secretions.

On Tzanck smear, which is a rapid, diagnostic method, Tzanck cells are seen. These are multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogenously stained ground-glass chromatin.

questions.text: Preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal or deviant conduct of man are called _______
questions.solution:
• Preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal or deviant conduct of man are called social defence.
  • This is in the form of acts, laws and judicial instructions for elements like juvenile delinquency, begging, prison reforms, gambling, etc.

questions.text: In laryngeal cancer, hoarseness of voice results from______
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness in glottis Ca is early because lesions of cord affect its vibratory capacity. 
  • Hoarseness in supraglottic and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:
    • Vocal cords with infiltration of thyroarytenoid muscle or
    • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve or
    • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.
  • Though this is a late feature, it is usually present at first presentation since patients usually come late.

questions.text: Which of the following mental disorders is a silent epidemic?
questions.solution:
Among mental disorders, Alzheimer’s disease is referred to as the silent epidemic of the century.

Nearly 50 million people globally are living with this disease, and since it strikes so often, so arbitrarily, and with such little warning, many have dubbed it the Silent Epidemic.

questions.text: Koplik’s spots with conjunctivitis are seen in ______.
questions.solution: Koplik’s spots are seen in measles.

questions.text: Ergonomics is __________.

choices.text: Fitting the job to the worker
Study of health in female workers

questions.solution: Ergonomics is defined as fitting the job to the worker. The objective of ergonomics is to achieve the best mutual adjustment of man and his work for the improvement of human efficacy and well being.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in:

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: The only neurons in retina showing action potential are _____
questions.solution: All neural elements in the retina exhibit local graded potentials except ganglion cells which shows action potential.

questions.text: A patient  who presented with bilateral proptosis is being investigated. Biopsy from the region shows _____
questions.solution:
The given biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

  • The biopsy picture shows hypocellular (Antony B) and hypercellular areas (Antony A).
  • Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows.
  • The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay Bodies.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease visits the fever clinic with a history of high-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite for the past 5 days. He has been diagnosed with moderate COVID 19 disease. The monoclonal antibody bamlanivimab is administered. Which part of the virus is it directed against?
questions.solution:
The patient who is diagnosed with moderate COVID-19 disease in a non-hospitalised set-up with a high risk of progression (DM, CKD and ≥65 years of age) can be treated with bamlanivimab. It is directed against the Sars-CoV-2 Spike protein.

Bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the spike (S) surface protein of SARS-CoV-2, designed to block the virus’s attachment and entry into human cells. Possible side effects include anaphylaxis and infusion-related reactions, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, itching, and vomiting. Etesevumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against the SARS-CoV-2 surface spike protein’s receptor binding domain.

Casirivimab and imdevimab consist of two antibodies that bind to different regions of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein receptor-binding domain.

Among ambulatory care patients, IDSA guidelines suggest the use of bamlanivimab/etesivimab in patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 who are at high risk for progression to severe disease. High-risk patients are those meeting at least one of the following criteria:  

  • Have a body mass index ≥35
  • Have chronic kidney disease
  • Have diabetes
  • Have immunosuppressive disease
  • Are currently receiving immunosuppressive treatment  
  • Are ≥65 years of age 
  • Are ≥55 years of age and have cardiovascular disease, or hypertension or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease/other chronic respiratory diseases  
  • Are 12–17 years of age and have BMI ≥85th percentile for their age and gender, or sickle cell disease, or congenital or acquired heart disease, or neurodevelopmental disorders, for example, cerebral palsy or asthma, reactive airway or other chronic respiratory diseases that requires daily medication for control

The following image shows the management algorithm:

The following image shows the structure of the virus:

NOTE:

FDA has recently expanded the emergency use authorization for the monoclonal antibody combination Bamlanivimab and Etesevimab. It can now be used for the treatment of mild to moderate COVID-19 and for post-exposure prophylaxis in all patients, including newborns who are at high risk for progression to severe COVID-19.

questions.text: A 10 year old girl has just started menstruating. She will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA in her village under:
questions.solution:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme which is a part of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram:

  • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years).
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (60mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid)
  • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA
  • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence.

The LAQSHYA initiative is for improving the quality of labour rooms and providing Respectful Maternity Care. It also includes expanding the obstetric ICUs at government medical college hospitals.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyaan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care so that a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check up in her 2nd or 3rd trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ 100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin, under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on 28-05-2018 (World mentrual hygiene day). ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs.1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendra for the underprivileged women of India.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck.  The features include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In an acute abscess,  air-fluid levels can be seen.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.

In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include

  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. 
  • Stridor and croupy cough 
  • Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. 
  • A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline. 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of

  • Caries of the cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with complaints of fever, anorexia, vomiting, abdominal pain and dark urine since 6 days. On investigation, he had elevated liver enzymes and serology was positive for IgM hepatitis A antibodies. Which of the following liver enzymes is most specific for his condition?
questions.solution:
The enzyme most specific for his condition, acute viral hepatitis, is alanine aminotransferase (ALT).

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is predominantly found in the liver and therefore is a more specific marker for hepatocellular damage than AST.

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is found in various tissues. AST/ALT ratio is very important.

  • AST/ALT <1 is seen in hepatocellular damage like in NAFLD, toxic hepatitis, paracetamol toxicity. In cirrhosis, the ratio becomes more than 1.
  • AST/ALT> 2 is suggestive while AST/ALT> 3 is highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

Alkaline phosphatase rise is seen in many liver diseases but more than fourfold rise indicates cholestasis.

GGT is used to identify occult alcohol use.

5'-Nucleotidase is specific for cholestasis.

Otits media is inflammation of the middle ear cleft.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident on a clinical elective in Guangzhou. You receive a patient with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facial pain. Which of the following do you see here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter’s triad/Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter’s syndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

Trotter’s triad consists of:

  • Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain.
  • Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.  

Option A - Samter’s triad seen in ethmoidal polyps consists of nasal polypi, asthma, and Aspirin intolerance

Option C - van der Hoeve syndrome is seen in otosclerosis consists of osteogenesis imperfecta, otosclerosis, and blue sclera

Option D - Kartagener syndrome consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Stapedotomy?
questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy.

Complications of stapedotomy:

  • SNHL
  • Facial palsy
  • Floating/ submerged footplate
  • Endolymph gusher due to damage to inner ear
  • Dislodgement of piston
  • Post-op vertigo

choices.text: DNA polymerase - copies DNA sequences in the polymerase chain reaction
DNA ligase - enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends
Reverse transcriptase - production of cDNA from mRNA

DNA ligase joins adjacent nucleotides in a covalent linkage.

Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific sites creating sticky ends.

questions.text: Light house sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
The lighthouse sign is seen is mastoiditis. It is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. It suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear.

Mastoiditis is a complication of ASOM.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows extension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the ring and little finger, caused by ulnar nerve injury. It produces a claw hand (main en griffe). Leprosy can affect peripheral nerves and lead to their associated conditions.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness of the ulnar one and a half fingers. 

Elbow fractures or dislocations lead to high lesions of the ulnar nerve. Here, the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus is paralyzed and the fingers, therefore, appear less clawed. This is called the high ulnar paradox.

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book forcefully while the doctor tries to pull it. In a positive test, due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. The patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, it is easy for the examiner to pull out the card when held between the fingers. This is due to the loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

 

 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to 'ape thumb' deformity. In forearm or elbow injuries, there is paralysis of long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, radial wrist flexors, and forearm pronators. This leads to the characteristic 'pointing index finger'. There is sensory loss over three and a half digits on the radial side. 

Option D -Posterior interosseous nerve injury, is seen in posterior interosseous syndrome. The wrist is in radial deviation and there is loss of metacarpophalangeal joint extension. However, wrist extension is preserved.

questions.text: The 10-year ASCVD (Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease ) risk score for a 45-year-old man is estimated to be >7.5%. Consumption of which of the following is associated with the greatest increase in cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
Among the given options saturated fatty acids is maximum in coconut oil, leading to an increased risk of elevated cholesterol level and cardiovascular events. 

Type of fat

Amount of saturated fat

(grams per tablespoon)
Coconut oil 11.8
Soybean oil 2.0
Sunflower oil 1.4
Safflower oil 0.8

Clinical correlate:

  • Consumption of saturated fats is associated with increased total and LDL cholesterol and an increased risk of coronary heart disease.
  • The WHO recommends that the intake of saturated fats should be less than 10% of the total energy intake.

questions.text: A 1.5kg male baby was delivered vaginally at 32 weeks of gestation. The infant was cyanotic and required CPAP immediately after delivery. His chest radiograph is shown below. A deficiency of which of the following phospholipids in the lungs is the likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and chest radiography image, showing diffuse bilateral opacities, is suggestive of infant respiratory distress syndrome caused by a deficiency of lung surfactant, dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (dipalmitoyl lecithin). It is primarily seen in premature infants.

Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, is found in the cell membranes of nervous tissue, particularly in the brain.

Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis.

Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as precursors of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with chronic liver disease presented with complaints of inability to straighten his ring finger completely as shown in the image. The broad sheet-like tendon involved in this condition is the______
questions.solution:
The condition shown above is Dupuytren's contracture. It is the contracture of the flat or broad sheet-like tendon known as the aponeurosis, which leads to flexion deformities of the fingers, especially the ring and little fingers.

The aponeurosis is a pearly-white sheet of fibrous tissue that replaces tendons in sheet-like muscles having wide areas of attachment. They are whitish-silvery in colour and shiny. It is similar to tendons in histology and are sparingly supplied with blood vessels and nerves.

Examples of aponeuroses include: 

  • Palmar aponeuroses on the palms of the hands
  • Plantar aponeuroses on the plantar aspect of the foot
  • Anterior abdominal aponeuroses superficial to the rectus abdominis muscles
  • Anterior and posterior intercostal membranes between the ribs
  • Scalp aponeuroses or galea aponeurotica in the scalp

 

Option A: The retinaculum is a strong, short, and broad fibrous band around the tendons which holds them in place.

Option B: The linear fibrous band formed by interdigitation of the tendinous or aponeurotic ends of the muscles is known as raphe.

Option D: Fascia is a generic term applied to sheaths, sheets or other dissectible masses of connective tissue that are large enough to be visible to the unaided eye.

questions.text: The heart starts to beat in the ______week of development.
questions.solution: The heart starts to beat in the 4th week of development.

questions.text: A resident was inserting a central venous line through the femoral vein. He accidentally injured the structure medial to the femoral vein, within the femoral sheath. Which structure is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic vessels lie medial to the femoral vein and are likely to be injured in this case.

Femoral sheath is the funnel-shaped prolongation of the fascia which contains femoral vessels. Anteriorly it is made of transversalis fascia and posteriorly it is made of fascia iliaca.

It is divided into three compartments:

  • The lateral compartment contains femoral artery
  • The intermediate compartment contains femoral vein
  • The medial compartment which is termed as femoral canal contains:
    • Lymphatic vessels
    • Areolar tissue
    • Lymph node of Cloquet. 

The empty space in the femoral canal allows distension of the adjacent femoral vein, so it can cope with increased venous return, or increased intra-abdominal pressure.

questions.text: The drug of choice for treatment of thyrotoxicosis during 1st trimester of pregnancy is______
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for treatment of thyrotoxicosis during 1st trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil.

Hyperthyroidism in pregnancy:

Pre-pregnancy and first trimester: Propylthiouracil 

2nd, 3rd trimester + post-pregnancy:

  • Methimazole
  • Partial thyroidectomy (in 2nd trimester if methimazole is not effective)

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure.

questions.text:
Arrange the coverings of the kidney from within outwards:

1. Renal fascia
2. Fibrous capsule
3. Paranephric fat
4. Perinephric fat
questions.solution:
The 4 coverings of the kidney from within outwards are as follows:

  1. True or fibrous capsule - formed by the collagen-rich connective tissue.
  2. Perinephric fat or adipose capsule - consists of fat and occupies the space between the fibrous capsule and the renal fascia.
  3. Renal fascia
  4. Paranephric fat - occupies the space between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia.

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria.

questions.solution: Transduction is a process of acquiring bacterial DNA from a phage that has incorporated bacterial DNA from previous host bacteria (bacteriophage).

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
Boundaries of the Calot’s triangle is not formed by the gall bladder.

Calot's triangle is formed by 3C's:

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery 

 

This is the most common site of injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) infusion prevents the closure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in term neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention.

Indomethacin is a NSAIDs indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in premature infants and neonates.

questions.text: Identify the image.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).

PCIOL:

  • They rest entirely behind the iris.
  • They may be supported and fixed as
    • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
    • Ciliary sulcus fixation
    • Sclera fixation

Parts of the IOL

  • The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic.
  • The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable indicator that the victim was alive while the fire was in progress?

choices.text: Vital reaction in the burned area
Redness of the exposed skin surface

questions.text: The finding on impedance audiometry in a long standing otosclerosis is  _____

choices.text: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
As graph with increased stapedial reflex

questions.solution:
Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear:

  • Tympanogram is a measure of the Tympanic membrane’s compliance or deflection to change in pressure. There are 5 types of graphs seen:
    • A: Normal individuals. It is the most common graph in general population.
    • As: Otosclerosis/Thick TM
    • Ad: Ossicular discontinuity/Thin TM
    • B: Perforation of TM
    • C: Eustachian tube Obstruction
  • Stapedial reflex: As the otosclerosis matures, the stapes footplate gets fixed and becomes immobile. Therefore, stapedial reflex is lost.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus?
questions.solution: Pneumocystis jiroveci is not a dimorphic fungus.

questions.text: You want to prescribe a drug that increases uveo-scleral outflow while treating a patient with open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you choose?
questions.solution: The class of anti-glaucoma drugs which act by increasing the uveo-scleral outflow are prostaglandin analogues.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts on the following stage of malarial parasite?
questions.solution:
The above image shows banana shaped gametocyte stage of Plasmodium Falciparum.

The antimalarial drugs which have gametocidal properties include chloroquine and primaquine.

Primaquine is used for 14 days as a tissue schizonticide for the purpose of reducing the likelihood of relapse due to hypnozoites of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale. It is also a potent gametocidal drug and is given as a single dose on day 2 for its gametocidal property in Plasmodium Falciparum.

Chloroquine acts primarily against erythrocytic asexual stages, although it has gametocidal properties.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
The drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis is edrophonium.

Muscle weakness is a common presentation in patients with myasthenia gravis and cholinergic crisis (excessive dose of anti-ChE drugs). Intravenous injection of edrophonium improves muscular weakness in a patient with myasthenia gravis and not in a case of cholinergic crisis. 

The test used for this differentiation is known as the edrophonium test. 

Initially, 2 mg is administered; if improvements of symptoms do not occur within 45 seconds, an additional 8 mg can be administered. Improvement of strength is a positive test for myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: On ocular examination,  a patient known to have inborn errors of metabolism shows the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows Kayser–Fleisher ring, which is seen in Wilson’s disease.
  • Another finding in Wilson’s disease: Sunflower cataract

questions.text: Through which of the following does glucose mediated insulin release occur?
questions.solution:
Glucose-mediated insulin release occurs through ATP sensitive K+ channels.

Increased blood glucose concentration is the primary controller of insulin secretion.

Inside the beta cells, glucose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate and later ATP is generated. This ATP closes ATP sensitive potassium channels, leading to a rise in K+ and depolarization. This in turn causes opening of voltage gated Ca 2+ channels and influx of Ca+. This ultimately leads to secretion of insulin via exocytosis.

questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of the transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon.
questions.solution:
The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon. It is formed from the lower fibers of the internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

Transversus Abdominis muscle:

Origin - from the internal surface of 7th-12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.

Insertion - at the linea alba with the aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: The most common cancer worldwide is lung cancer
The most common malignant tumors of the lung are metastases
The most common cause of cancer mortality worldwide is lung cancer
The lung is the most common site of metastatic neoplasms

questions.solution:
According to Globocan 2020, the most common cancer worldwide is breast cancer. However, lung cancer remains the leading overall cause of cancer mortality.

Lung cancers:

  • The most common malignant tumors of the lung are metastases/ secondaries.
  • The most common primary malignant tumor of the lung is bronchogenic cancer.
  • The most common histology is adenocarcinoma (43.8%), followed by squamous cell (26.2%).

questions.text: A surgeon is to perform a mastoidectomy procedure for a patient with CSOM. He uses the following instrument during the procedure. What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

Shown below is Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor.

questions.text: In men, LH controls secretion of______
questions.solution:
In men, LH controls the secretion of testosterone.

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH by a negative feedback mechanism. FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to secrete inhibin, which in turn inhibits FSH by a negative feedback mechanism.

Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. Inhibin acts directly on the anterior pituitary to inhibit FSH secretion.

FSH also stimulates the secretion of ABP (androgen-binding protein) and inhibin. FSH and androgens maintain the gametogenic function of the testes. Hypothalamic lesions in animals and hypothalamic disease in humans lead to atrophy of the testes and loss of their function.

questions.text: Principal site of acidification of urine______
questions.solution:
Principal site of acidification of urine is collecting duct. Acidification occurs in both distal tubule and collecting duct, but collecting duct is more important. 

The urinary pH of 4.5 (limiting pH) is normally reached in the collecting ducts. 

In the late distal tubules and collecting ducts, the tubular epithelium secretes H+ by primary active transport. Primary active secretion of H+ occurs in type A intercalated cells of the late distal tubule and in the collecting tubules. H+ concentration can be increased as much as 900-fold in the collecting tubules.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. This is seen in myopia.

Definitions of refractive errors:

Myopia—Short-sightedness: The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focussed in front of the retina when accommodation is at rest.

Hypermetropia—Long-sightedness: The parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina when accommodation is at rest.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the secondary level of the healthcare system?
questions.solution: Medical colleges are included in the tertiary level of the health care system, which is also the second referral centre.

questions.text: Deficiency of arginosuccinate synthetase results in ______.
questions.solution:
Deficiency of arginosuccinate synthetase results in Citrullinemia.

Other options:

  • Hyperargininemia is due to a deficiency of arginase.
  • Argininosuccinic aciduria is due to a deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase.
  • Hyperammonemia type 1 due to a deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is called oriental lung fluke?
questions.solution: Paragonimus westermani is commonly known as oriental lung fluke or Japanese lung fluke.

questions.text: The drug of choice in Zollinger Ellison syndrome is ______
questions.solution:
Proton-pump inhibitors are the drug of choice in Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. There is secretion of large amounts of gastrin, which inturn increases gastric acid leading to severe gastroduodenal ulceration and other effects of hyperchlorhydria.

Treatment of ZES: High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

Distal Pancreatectomy – if a lesion in the body or tail of the pancreas
Enucleation – if a lesion in the head of the pancreas
Full-thickness excision – if lesion in duodenum
MEN associated – surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: In which of the following cellular organelles does HMP shunt occur?
questions.solution: HMP shunt takes place in the cytosol as enzymes needed for the HMP shunt (pentose phosphate) pathway are located in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: In a patient with referred back pain, a surgeon suspects the origin of pain to be from a retroperitoneal organ. Which of the following is the likely cause of pain?
questions.solution:
The pancreas is a retroperitoneal structure. All the other structures listed are intraperitoneal. Pain originating from retroperitoneal organs are likely to be referred to the back.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked as A?

choices.text: It is part of the Waldeyer's ring
Hypertrophies up to the age of 6 years and regresses by puberty
It is surrounded by a capsule

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the adenoids. It is not surrounded by a capsule.

Adenoids are comprised of vertical ridges of lymphoid tissues separated by deep clefts. They form the superior aspect of Waldeyer's ring. They have no crypts and no capsule, unlike palatine tonsils which have both.

It is present at birth, enlarges up to the age of 6 years, and then regresses by puberty. It completely disappears by the age of 20 years.

questions.text: Surface marking of the oblique fissure of the lung includes  ________
questions.solution:
On either side, the upper and lower lobes of the lung are separated by the oblique fissure.

This can be marked by a line that runs anteroinferiorly from the posterior end of the 4th rib (spinous process of the T3 vertebra), crosses the 5th rib in the mid­axillary line, continues inferiorly, crossing either the 6th intercostal space/ 7th rib on the right or the 5th rib/ 5th intercostal space on the left, on both sides at the mid­clavicular line.

Left oblique fissure is located at a higher level and courses more vertically than the right oblique fissure.

questions.text: Among the following criteria, which is the most reliable criterion for age determination from Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
According to Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion.

Gustafson's method of estimating the age of an individual is based on physiological changes in dental tissues. It is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age (option B).

Gustafson’s criteria:

  • Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication
  • Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity
  • Cementum apposition - Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root due to changes in the tooth position. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves 
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Other options:

Option C - Weight and height of the erupting teeth of a child are used to estimate the age of infants by Stack's method, not Gustafson's method.

Option D -  Chemical methods for estimation of the nitrogen content of enamel, which increases with age, are used for estimating the age beyond 25 years. It is not a part of Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient came with complaints of easy fatiguability and palpitations. On examination, she had pallor. Methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine was estimated as a part of evaluation. This can be utilized to assess the nutritional status of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
The above scenario suggests anemia and methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine can be utilized to assess the nutritional status of vitamin B12.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine.

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

Note: Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Disability prevention by appropriate treatment is a mode of intervention in ____.
questions.solution:
Disability prevention by appropriate treatment is a mode of intervention that is used as secondary prevention. (Treatment is the key word here).

After the disability has set in, prevention of progression of disability from transitioning into a handicap is tertiary prevention. It is also called disability limitation.

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents with the multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. The tissue biopsy was done and sent to the laboratory for culture. On microscopy, the flower-like clusters of conidia as shown in the image below are seen. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is _____
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is a chronic infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. It usually follows spreads along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes.

The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules.

Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Laboratory diagnosis includes direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain showing the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Image showing asteroid body:

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: The stain used for melanin in the below image is
questions.solution:
The stain used for melanin in the above image is Masson Fontana stain. Other stains for melanin are Schmorl’s method and an enzyme histochemical method called DOPA oxidase method. This DOPA oxidase method is the most specific stain for melanin.

Other options:

  • Oil red stains neutral lipids and fatty acids
  • PAS stains glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoproteins and fungi
  • Gomori methamine stains fungi

questions.text: Activation energy is free energy difference between the _______
questions.solution:
Activation energy is free energy difference between the Substrate & transition State.

Activation energy may also be defined as the minimum energy required to start a chemical reaction.

Enzyme increases the rate of reaction by reducing the activation energy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She feels nauseous and as if the room is spinning. The symptoms subside after a few minutes but return when she moves her head. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

questions.text: A researcher finds out a sensitive test to be positive for a person. For diagnosis, which of the following will hold true?

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.solution:
• Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of the test to identify correctly those who have the disease.
  • In other words, it confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common.

questions.text: Osmoreceptors that control osmolality of body fluids are located in ______.
questions.solution:
Osmoreceptors that control osmolality of body fluids are located in anterior hypothalamus.
