questions.text: A deceased male was posted for a ​post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes should be examined in this case.

Some amount of material or dye used for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Hence in cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined before making any conclusions.

questions.text: The Sparsh campaign was launched to spread awareness about which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of anti-leprosy day (observed on the last Sunday of January) to promote awareness about leprosy.

Objectives of SLAC are to create mass awareness in the community on leprosy, to reduce stigma and discrimination in the community and for early detection of Leprosy cases. 

Sapna refers to a local school-going girl who will help to spread awareness in the community.

The other developments under NLEP are:

  • Mycobacterium Indicus Prani (MiP) vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts (it is in a project mode).
  • Nikusth: A web-based system for the data management of leprosy cases.

Note: Meena is a nine-year-old girl, who is the symbol of UNICEF's Girl Empowerment programme to impart important messages on gender, child rights, education, health and development in the South Asian region.

The posters below depict the role play by Sapna:

World Leprosy Day is celebrated on 30 January. This international day is an opportunity to celebrate people who have experienced leprosy, raise awareness of the disease, and call for an end to leprosy-related stigma and discrimination. The “United for Dignity” campaign calls for unity in honoring the dignity of people who have experienced leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
questions.solution:
National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. 
  • National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number.

Ayushman Bharat Diwas is being celebrated across the country on April 30.

questions.text: Denominator of maternal mortality ratio is:

choices.text: Total women in child bearing age

questions.solution:
The denominator of the maternal mortality ratio is total live births.

MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period

questions.text: Chikungunya virus is transmitted by ________
questions.solution:
Chikungunya is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with cardiac dysrhythmia. On probing, he says he consumed the leaves of the plant shown in the image. What is the active principle of this plant?
questions.solution:
The plant in the image is Digitalis purpurea. Its active principle is digitonin.

Digitalis purpurea contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin. It can cause cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: What is the most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the liver.

40% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts are derived from the biliary epithelium.

Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved.

questions.text: The enzyme elevated in the first two hours of myocardial infarction is _____.
questions.solution:
Enzymes with elevated levels within 2 to 4 hours of myocardial infarction are creatine kinase MB fraction (CK-MB) and troponins.

Note: 

Myoglobin is the earliest enzyme to show increased levels after MI. However, it is not specific for cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.

Among the given options, CK-MB is the best possible answer.

questions.text: The parvocellular pathway from the lateral geniculate body (LGB) to the visual cortex carries signals for the detection of ______.

choices.text: Colour vision, shape, and fine details

questions.solution:
Parvocellular pathway

  • From layers 3, 4, 5, and 6 of the lateral geniculate body (LGB)
  • Gives signals for color vision, texture, shape, and fine details
  • To layer 4 of the visual cortex

Magnocellular pathway

  • From layers 1 and 2 of LGB
  • Gives signals for movement, depth, flicker, and spatial organization
  • To layer 4 of the visual cortex

Interlaminar pathway

  • Gives signals for color vision to layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex having clusters of cells called blobs.

Image: Visual representation of the parvocellular and magnocellular pathways

questions.text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is _____
questions.solution:
The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II.

Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

Related Pearl: Actions of Angiotensin II

  • Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP.
  • Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion.
  • Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons.
  • Contraction of mesangial cells with a resultant decrease in GFR.
  • Direct effect on renal tubules will increase Na+ reabsorption.
  • Acts on the brain to decrease the sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II.
  • Acts on the brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH.

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia and achlorhydria. After evaluation, pernicious anemia is diagnosed. Damage to which of the following cells is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Pernicious anemia develops due to autoimmune damage to the parietal cells in gastric glands.

The parietal cells secrete both HCl and intrinsic factor. Therefore, when the parietal cells are destroyed, both achlorhydria, as well as pernicious anemia, develop.

Pernicious anemia occurs due to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle, which is important for the absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.text: All of the following are methods used to detect the three dimensional structure of proteins except _____.
questions.solution:
Electrophoresis is not used to detect the three-dimensional structure of proteins.

The techniques used to determine the three-dimensional structures of proteins are as follows:

  • X-Ray crystallography
  • NMR spectroscopy
  • Infra-red spectroscopy
  • Polychromatic X-ray crystallography
  • UV light spectroscopy
  • Optical rotatory dispersion
  • Circular dichromism
  • Computer-based modelling
  • Mass spectrometry

questions.text: For a man to be found guilty of statutory rape, he must have had sexual intercourse with?

choices.text: A woman who is in intoxicated state
His wife living under decree of separation
Any person other than his wife
A girl below 18 years of age with her consent

questions.solution:
Statutory rape is having a sexual relationship with a girl who is below 18 years of age even with her consent.

Sexual intercourse with a woman who is under the influence of sedative drugs like GHB, rohypnol (flunitrazepam) is called date rape. 

Sexual intercourse with wife living separately, against her consent is marital rape. 

Voluntary sexual intercourse between a married person and a person who is not their spouse is adultery.

Note: Adultery used to be a punishable offence under Section 497 IPC. It was scapped down by the Supreme Court on 6th September 2018, and is no longer punishable.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest glycemic index?
questions.solution:
The Glycemic index is highest for glucose.

The increase in blood glucose after a test dose of carbohydrate compared with that after an equivalent amount of glucose (as glucose or from a reference starchy food) is known as the glycemic index.

Glycemic Index:

  • Glucose and galactose: 1
  • Dietary fibers: 0

Low glycemic index:

  • Fructose
  • Sucrose
  • Starch
  • Sugar alcohol

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly and a boiled cabbage odour. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is treated by a combination of nitisone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia and vitamin D resistant rickets.

Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

Note: A boiled cabbage odour can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: The given image depicts:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a frequency polygon.

Note:

A line graph depicts a time-trend and has time as the x-axis. In the given graph above, the x-axis is the value of Hb concentration.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with mild squint. The history is quite insignificant. On examination, the corneal reflex is found to be normal. All other eye parameters are also normal except for an exaggerated epicanthal fold. The most likely diagnosis would be ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pseudoesotropia.

Features of Pseudoesotropia

  • Apparent convergent squint
  • Prominent epicanthal fold
  • Negative angle kappa

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution: The above image shows a dimeric structure which is characteristic of secretory IgA.

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with erectile dysfunction, his internal pudendal artery was found to be stenosed. Which of the following​ vessels is this a branch of?

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to the internal pudendal artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery(in males)
  • Inferior vesical artery (in males)
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior division of internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: Identify the appearance of the organism based on the image below.
questions.solution: The image shows the “fish in stream appearance”  of Vibrio cholerae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of both feet and of breathlessness on exertion. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with cardiac failure.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

questions.text: An asthmatic patient complains of wheezing and shortness of breath most days of the week. Which of the following therapies is preferred in him?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent asthma for which the preferred therapy is LABA with ICS available as a combination inhaler.

ICS should be started in any patient who needs to use a short-acting beta-2 agonist inhaler for symptomatic control more than twice a week (persistent asthma).

questions.text: You have to counsel a patient regarding their diet and the proportion of macronutrients that should be present in their food.  Which of the following statements will you make regarding the daily intake of fats, carbohydrates and proteins?

choices.text: Proteins must constitute 15-30% of your daily energy  intake.
Fats must constitute 10-15% of your daily energy intake.
The carbohydrate requirement must be met first while constructing the daily diet.
The proportion of the nutrients taken daily must be: carbohydrates> fats> proteins.

questions.solution:
The percentage of the nutrients in a balanced diet must be: carbohydrates> fats> proteins.

While constructing a balanced diet:

  • The protein requirements must be met first- 10-15% of the daily energy intake.
  • The fat requirement should be limited to- 15-30%
  • Carbohydrates rich in natural fibres should constitute the remaining food energy.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not associated with purine degradation?
questions.solution:
Orotic aciduria is not associated with purine degradation. 

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by the deficiency of orotidylate decarboxylase or UMP synthase. It is the most common metabolic error in the synthesis of pyrimidines.

Gout, severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID) and purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP) deficiency are associated with purine degradation.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy sample of a patient showed Reed-Sternberg cells that were CD15 & CD30 negative. Which of the variants of Hodgkin lymphoma is the patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy findings of CD15 and CD30 negative Reed–Sternberg cell is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 for most subtypes, except in lymphocyte-predominant HL, in which the neoplastic cells stains for CD20 and BCL-6.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man underwent surgery for an indirect inguinal hernia. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally injured a nerve which has led to decreased sensation over the anterior one-third region of the scrotum and anteromedial region of the thigh. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The genitofemoral nerve is likely to be injured. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve innervates the anterior one-third of the scrotum, and the femoral branch innervates the anteromedial region of the thigh. 

Part of the scrotum Nerve supply Root value
Anterior one-third

Ilioinguinal nerve

Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

  L1
Posterior two-third

Perineal branch of the posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh

Posterior scrotal branches of the perineal nerve

  S3 

Clinical note: Considering the root values of the nerves supplying the scrotum, the spinal block should be given above the level of L1 to anesthetise it.

questions.text: During the cardiac cycle, the opening of the aortic valve takes place at the ______
questions.solution:
Opening of the aortic valve takes place at the end of the isovolumetric contraction.
When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary valves) open, and ventricular ejection begins.

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
The image shows inflammation and hypopyon. These signs, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery, suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis. The management is to administer intravitreal antibiotics.

The majority of patients with postoperative endophthalmitis present with an acute onset and within seven days after surgery.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.

The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and decrease in vision.

The patient classically presents with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis. 

Other treatments:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Cycloplegia
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

questions.text: What is the end product of breakdown of purine nucleotides?
questions.solution:
Uric acid is the end product of purine catabolism.

Inside the intestinal mucosal cells, purine nucleotides are sequentially degraded by specific enzymes to nucleosides and free bases, with uric acid as the end product of this pathway.The free bases are sent out from the liver and salvaged by peripheral tissues.

Allantoin is the end product of purine catabolism in mammals and other primates. Uricase converts uric acid to water-soluble allantoin.

Related Pearl: Enzymes and Steps Involved in Purine Degradation

Enzymes

Reaction

AMP to IMP

Adenosine deaminase

Adenosine to Inosine

5'-nucleotidase

IMP & GMP to Inosine & Guanosine respectively

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase

Inosine & Guanosine to Hypoxanthine & guanine respectively

Xanthine oxidase

Hypoxanthine to Xanthine & Xanthine to uric acid

questions.text: The most common cancer of the esophagus is______.
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common tumor of the esophagus worldwide and also in India.

Squamous cell carcinoma is most often seen in upper two-thirds of the esophagus, whereas adenocarcinoma is more frequent in the lower one-third of the esophagus.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mortality in patients with organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution: The most common cause of death in organophosphate poisoning is respiratory failure. It usually occurs within 24 hours in untreated patients, secondary to paralysis of respiratory muscles.

questions.text: Where is the sinus of Morgagni present?

choices.text: Between middle constrictor and inferior constrictor
Between superior constrictor and middle constrictor

questions.solution:
Sinus of Morgagni is a gap present between the base of the skull and the upper border of superior constrictor muscle.

Structures passing through the sinus of Morgagni are as follows:

  • Palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Levator veli palatini muscle
  • Eustachian tube

Note: Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter's triad is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by:

  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Ipsilateral immobility of the palate
  • Neuralgic pain.

questions.text: FSH receptor is present in_____
questions.solution:
• Granulosa cells express the FSH receptor.
  • Theca interna cells express LH receptor.

Theca interna cells have many LH receptors. LH acts via cAMP to increase conversion of cholesterol to androstenedione. The theca interna cells supply androstenedione to the granulosa cells. The granulosa cells make estradiol when provided with androgens.

Granulosa cells have many FSH receptors. FSH facilitates their secretion of estradiol by acting via cAMP to increase their aromatase activity. Mature granulosa cells also acquire LH receptors, and LH also stimulates estradiol production.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia was started on a class1B anti-arrhythmic drug. Identify the drug.
questions.solution: Mexiletine is a class 1B antiarrhythmic drug. It is a lidocaine analog.

questions.text: The carrying capacity of any population is determined by its _________
questions.solution: The carrying capacity is the number of individuals of a certain population that can be supported in a certain area for a period of time given the resources of that area. Thus, the carrying capacity is determined by the limiting resources of an area.

questions.text: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:

  • V = volume of compartment
  • Amount injected = 500 mg
  • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg
  • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL

Calculation:

2nd method : 

Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid 

Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of ECF (x)

Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x 

From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as

      3.2/100 = 450/x

Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL

                    = 14,062.5 mL

                    = 14 L

Clinical :

IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.text: A college student on MAO inhibitor therapy for depression consumed two bottles of beer during a party. The next day he started experiencing severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He was taken to the casualty by his friends where his BP was recorded to be 180/110mmHg. Which of the following compounds would be responsible for this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of a hypertensive crisis in a patient on MAO inhibitor therapy is suggestive of cheese reaction, which is seen after consumption of foods rich in tyramine (beer).

Tyramine is an indirect sympathomimetic. It induces the release of catecholamines from the neurons. Tyramine can be produced in high concentrations in protein-rich foods by decarboxylation of tyrosine during fermentation.

Normally tyramine is inactivated when taken orally because it is readily metabolized by MAO in the liver. In patients who are on MAO inhibitor therapy, the tyramine taken in the diet is not inactivated and results in its increased sympathomimetic effect resulting in elevated blood pressure, termed as hypertensive crisis or cheese reaction.

When MAO inhibitors are taken along with SSRI or TCA, it results in serotonin syndrome due to the overstimulation of 5HT receptors. The clinical features are a triad of:

  1. Cognitive effect - delirium, coma
  2. Autonomic effects- hypertension, tachycardia
  3. Somatic effects- myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremors

questions.text: A baby, about 30 days old, is brought with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. He has a large and hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario fits the description of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG)

It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Several genes have been implicated, prominently CYP1B1.

Diagnosis

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring
  • Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; sevoflurane lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following is often biopsied to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions in the lymph nodes?

choices.text: Largest lymph node in the region of the primary tumor
Smallest lymph node in the region of the primary tumor
First lymph node that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor
Last lymph node that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor

questions.solution:
• The sentinel lymph node, which is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor, is often used to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions in the lymph nodes.
  • Sentinel node mapping can be done by the injection of radiolabeled tracers or colored dyes, and examination of frozen sections of the sentinel lymph node performed during surgery can guide the surgeon to the appropriate therapy.
  • Sentinel node examination has also been used for detecting the spread of melanomas, colon cancers, and other tumors.

questions.text: Conjunctival epithelium is _______.
questions.solution:
Conjunctival epithelium is stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium.

Anatomy of the conjunctiva

 It is divided into the following:

  • The palpebral conjunctiva starts at the mucocutaneous junction of the lid margins and is firmly attached to the posterior surface of the tarsal plates. 
  • The forniceal conjunctiva is loose and redundant.
  • The bulbar conjunctiva covers the anterior sclera and is continuous with the corneal epithelium at the limbus. Radial ridges at the limbus form the palisades of Vogt, the likely reservoir of corneal stem cells. 

Histology of conjunctiva

  • The epithelium is non-keratinizing and around five cell-layers deep. Mucin-secreting goblet cells are located within the epithelium and are most dense inferonasally (nasal>inferior) and in the fornices.
  • The stroma (substantia propria) consists of richly vascularized loose connective tissue. The accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring are located deep within the stroma.
  • Conjunctiva-associated lymphoid tissue (CALT) is critical in the initiation and regulation of ocular-surface immune responses.

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve pass through?
questions.solution:
The mandibular nerve passes through the foramen ovale which is marked as A in the above image.

Other foramina marked in the above image:

  • C - Internal acoustic meatus
  • D - Jugular foramen

questions.text: Which of the following is not true in disaster management?

choices.text: Mitigation involves measures to prevent hazards causing emergency
Rescue and evacuation occurs in recovery phase
In triage, yellow colour is for medium priority.
Gastroenteritis is the commonest infection after disaster.

questions.solution:
Rescue and evacuation occur in the response phase (not in the recovery phase).

The disaster management cycle:

questions.text: The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is ________
questions.solution:
The main site of peripheral vascular resistance is precapillary arterioles.

Poiseuille—Hagen formula explains that small changes in the calibre of vessels cause large changes in total peripheral resistance.

Where,

R=resistance
η=viscosity
L=length of the tube
r=radius of the tube

The resistance varies inversely with the fourth power of radius.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the ophthalmoscopy done by the instrument shown in the image below?

choices.text: Area of field in focus is 2 disc diameters.
The image produced is real and inverted.

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and the procedure is known as indirect ophthalmoscopy.

Indirect ophthalmoscopy produces an inverted, or reversed, real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

Area of field in focus is about 8 disc diameters

Condensing lens is usually required, and stereopsis is present.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding breakpoint chlorination except:

choices.text: Free chlorine is released in water after breakpoint chlorination
Chlorine demand is the amount needed to kill bacteria, oxidize organic matter and neutralize ammonia
0.5 ppm of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached
Contact period of 1 hour is necessary

questions.solution:
The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. 

0.5 ppm (0.5 mg) of free chlorine must be present in water after the breakpoint has been reached.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the test being performed on a patient by an ENT resident as shown below?

choices.text: It is lateralized to worse ear in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome
It is heard equally on both sides in normal individual
It is lateralized towards better ear in cochlear otosclerosis
It is lateralized towards worse ear in Ménière’s disease

questions.solution:
The image shows the Weber test being performed. Ménière’s disease causes sensorineural hearing loss and hence Weber test is lateralized towards the better ear. 

In Weber's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.

It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

Option A: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the worse ear.

Option B: In normal individuals, the sound is heard equally in both ears. So Weber is not lateralized. 

Option C: Cochlear otosclerosis causes sensorineural deafness, whereas stapedial otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the better ear in case of cochlear otosclerosis.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: If the cause of death remains unknown even after detailed laboratory investigations, it is known as?
questions.solution:
If the cause of death remains unknown even after detailed laboratory investigations, it is known as negative autopsy.

Negative autopsy : An autopsy in which, the cause of death remains unknown, even after all laboratory examinations including biochemical, microbiological, virological, microscopic and toxicological examination is known negative autopsy.

Obscure autopsy : An autopsy done meticulously, but presents with no clear-cut findings as to give a definite cause of death, is defined as obscure autopsy. Further lab investigations are required to know the details of the cause of death in this type of autopsy
